I don't eat from ANYONE even if I'm very hungry, fearing there might be something mixed in the food and i might get robbed. I always book the upper berth cuz if i get lower, I'll have to deal with arguing with people who ask for exchange and i don't want to have that conversation. And in the upper berth, you don't have to deal with getting up and adjusting with middle berth guy for sitting- another conversation avoided.  I always stay on my upper berth and come down only when I've arrived at my station cuz i really don't want any conversation with anyone. Side upper is ideally the best but I'm too tall and my leg hurts having to bend it to fit myself there. 

But damn bro after watching this video I feel like I've missed out on so many experiences... You know what? Ima change. Let's see.

Back when I was in school. I have travelled from West Bengal to Bangalore took 3 days. Then when my family had to go to Maharashtra we took the train via Delhi , West Bengal-Delhi-Mumbai. But back then smartphone didn't exist so never knew that people can even blog on these stuffs. Blogging while brushing, while eating. Even now a lot of people travel via train for 3 days. But for the elite classes like you all these things seem very fancy. And finally people watching this video, please don't order via IRCTC catering they provide worst food. I traveled in this train 6 years ago,end to end-- in general(Unreserved). I can see now that the train time has been speeded up a bit-- those days it would depart around 2230 Saturday Ex  DBRG and arrive in CAPE at around 1000 on Wednesday.  This is probably due to the change in route. Previously, it would take the Northern Dooar route between Alipurduar and NJP whereas now it takes the southern (still not the mainline chord). Also, previously it would take the ASN_ADRA_KGP route, but now it caresses Kolkata a bit. 
All in all a memorable experience.
To add a bit-- this was my attempt at visiting extremes of Indian Railway network- Ledo in East, CAPE in South, Varvala (Gujarat) in West and Kashmir in the North. All my journeys were in Sleeper+Unreserved class. Unfortunately my sleeper reservation went W/L and therefore I had to travel UR.

As for your ending statement: I did a similar tour in Kerala not so long ago and organized everything by myself on the spot. Sure, nothing wrong with a tour, but if you have a tiny bit of travel experience, visiting Kerala on your own is really straight forward. Its well organized, people speak english and are helpful. I can really recommend to everyone to try it. Its so much fun and you are more exposed to the "real" india than on a guided tour.

After watching travel videos showcasing beautiful countries, I always thought, "Wow, how gorgeous they look! I need to experience this." But today, I saw a video about Kerala, India, and it made me realize something important. I've been to the same places shown in the video, but my experience was completely different. It hit me that the quality of a travel experience isn't just about the destinationâ€”it's about how much money you can spend. With enough money, even a place like India can look spectacular. For example, the resort featured in the video costs about a month's salary for the average Indian. In the end, it all boils down to how much you can afford to spend. The more money you have, the more beautiful and luxurious your trip will be. Also STOP editing the footage to make it look beautiful.

Your photography is some of the best I've seen of my home state! I lived in Munnar (pronounced MOON-AAR, by the way) the first 4 years of my life. My grandfather built the reservoir (and the dam/hydroelectric project) near there that you briefly showed! The diversity of India is something that most people in the West can't grasp... I sometimes ask them to imagine if Europe was one big country, it would be something like what India with our conglomeration of our states is like. Kerala is about as different from, say, Punjab, as Sweden is from Italy or Poland. It's also as different from its neighboring states as European countries are from theirs. More different actually -- almost every European language uses the same script. We have a different script for each language, and each state has a different language. I'm glad you were able to appreciate our diversity.

It was so nice to see them again after all this time. If you ever get the chance to go back to India, riding a train is such an adventure. There are men who hop onto the train at every stop with chai /tea and they will do that one meter trick to help cool down the tea quickly. See, This is my message to all foreigners... I have been binge watching different people explore India and I just have like a ton to say... I wanna let my anger out, So just hear me...

Out of all states in India, Kerala is the cleanest... Has the most amount of english speaking people than any other state and is the the 1st state of India to gain 100% education... Literally anyone you meet will be school passed and not illiterate... And now, for the brown stereotype (brown munde)... Please don't think that everyone is brown or black, You know I myself am white, and i know tons of people who are too... Kerala is the best state in the whole entire India, and that's why it's called "God's own Country". 

Sorry, If I offended any fellow Indian... I just wanted to let my anger out, seeing all those stereotype from binge watching these things...

Many american, french, spanish or koreans come to India and make vlogs... but what they are unintentionally doing is going to places, where even us Indians won't go 'cause it's not safe... 
And You know what they will do? They will upload these videos in such manner that it makes our country look dirty... That everyone is POOR and isn't EDUCATED...
Why go to such places, and ruin our damn reputation when you can come to a state like Kerala, or Sikkim or any Eastern States as they are also so stunning and beautiful... and again just like Kerala , They are very clean...

STOP! stereotyping us and going to places where even we won't and then ruining our country's status... It's because of you guys, that India is thought to be poor... It's because of you guys, that hollywood has normalised stereotypical accents... Not everyone speaks like that you know! I myself and my family do have great accents that sounds like we are from america, but we are not!

What Allison said is True: "The only good thing americans think about India is the Taj Mahal"

I HOPE this helps people change their mindset, and i want YOU guys to help spread this message! Use #StopStereotypingIndia and spread this message to all damn social media platforms...

I wish you a GOOD DAY  <3

To be honest when I arrived in Kerala and saw the â€œGodâ€™s own Countryâ€ catch phrase from its tourism department, I kind of rolled my eyes. But somewhere along my trip, as I took in the natural beauty and the love from its people, I gradually realized I didnâ€™t even want to leave that place. It truly was Godâ€™s own country. It had a way of making everyone feel at home. I still feel like I belong there and I am a malayali (although I donâ€™t speak the language). One of most beautiful places Iâ€™ve ever been and thatâ€™s not just the nature, but people too.

As someone who has travelled to Europe and South East Asia - the latter especially places like Kerala (India in general) are so much welcoming than places like Italy or France where they frown upon foreigners (especially Americans). In contrast Malayalis (thatâ€™s what people from Kerala call themselves) are so thrilled to show you around. Every local Iâ€™ve met have been super friendly and helpful. Whenever Iâ€™ve been to Europe all I get is contempt for America and some pretentious bs about how everything there is more authentic and better than the rest of the world. In India I felt people appreciate me as a tourist more, they welcome your questions and accept you to a degree that you canâ€™t even remotely experience in France / Italy.

India is very diverse in its food, culture , topography, climate, language. Hope u have a pleasant fullfilling wholesome experience.
I know u many be having doubts about safety and cleanliness. 
A tip from my part -
1. Wear what the locals are wearing. It will give u a whole different respect and acceptance. Kurtas are the best choice as they are accepted throught out.
If not wear jeans and shirts/tops - try avoiding too revealing ones. Not saying ppl are bad . But many might feel more comfortable if u wear things that they have been used to seeing
2. India has rich ppl , middle class and poor ppl and that separation is evident. Go where the middle class go.. That would be economical and healthy too.
3. Dont trust everyone. And politely deny ppl asking for selfies
4. Police are very particular about safety of foreigners.
5. Most ppl are very welcoming and ready to help. Just avoid the ones that u are doubtful about. If u have doubts or need help its best to ask a family group or a college group than  single individuals. If u feel unsafe stay close to family groups and college groups
6. Avoid cheap hotels. Go for middle class ones

Want to visit temple-- odisha

 Population and pollution--- go for UP, bihar, mumbai


Iconic  places still exist today--- UP


Mountain-- Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand  


Golden temple --- punjab


Desert and kings palace--- Rajasthan


Snowfall ---- Kashmir, Jammu, Ladakh, uttarakhand and other northern state


               Most important thing. India is single country but different state people speak different language. Culture, tradition,looks vary from one state to another. You will feel like INDIA is like a small  CONTINENT of its own.
